documentation.title: Angular Standalone Components (v15+, default from v17+)
documentation.summary: Standalone components, directives, and pipes don't need to be declared in an NgModule. From Angular 17+, standalone: true is the default and can be omitted.
bestPractices: From Angular 19+, `standalone: true` is the default â€” no need to specify it explicitly
Import other standalone components/directives/pipes directly in the `imports` array of @Component
Lazy load standalone components in routes: `loadComponent: () => import('./path').then(m => m.MyComponent)`
For shared functionality, create barrel files or utility functions instead of SharedModules
If still using NgModules, use `importProvidersFrom()` to bridge the gap
commonMistakes: Forgetting to import dependencies directly in standalone component's `imports` array
Importing CommonModule when only specific directives are needed (import NgIf, NgFor individually, or better: use @if/@for)
Still using NgModules when standalone components would simplify the architecture
Not lazy loading standalone components in routes when possible
Using HttpClientModule instead of provideHttpClient() in standalone apps
In Angular 19+, specifying `standalone: true` explicitly is redundant (still works but unnecessary)
